_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PURPOSE FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION / UPDATE



Stolthaven Houston Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan (RMP) in February of 2014 to revise the operating scenario for a regulated toxic substance already handled at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, to revise the program level for those RMP covered processes that are also subject to the Occupational Health and Safety Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, to update the terminal's five year accident history, to update relevant facility contact information, and to update various RMP data elements that have changed since the previous plan update submitted in January of 2011.  The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:



- Updating the RMP due to Stolthaven Houston Inc. commencing the storage and associated parcel shipments of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) from the facility's D-Tank Farm in existing Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-19 above the TDI threshold quantity of 10,000-pounds.  Stolthaven Houston currently stores TDI in two existing Low-Pressure Tanks also located in the facility's D-Tank Farm (Tanks D-15-22 and D-30-10) as represented in previous RMP submittals



- Updating the five-year accident history to include an unplanned release of TDI that occurred on the evening of August 23, 2013



- Minor RMP data element updates based on revisions to Stolthaven Houston's Emergency Action Plan (EAP) and revisions to our Standard Operating Procedures found in the terminal's Local Training Manual (LTM)



- Updating the site's Emergency Contact and the contact information for the Terminal Manager responsible for RMP implementation at Stolthaven Houston Inc.  



- Changing the D-Tank Farm TDI Storage Process and the three Pentane Intermodal Transfer Processes to reflect RMP Program Level 3 coverage





? 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



At Stolthaven Houston Inc. we are committed to operating and maintaining

all of our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees, our industrial neighbors, and the citizens of the surrounding communities.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston Inc. has designed and implemented, including:



- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR Part 68 that are currently handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding threshold quantities (TQ)



- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs



- A five-year history of significant accidental releases from processes covered by EPA's RMP regulations



- An overview of our emergency response programs



- An overview of recent improvements at the facility implemented to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets



- Detailed information about our Risk Management Program





? 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Stolthaven Houston Inc. owns and operates an existing bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 158 large above-ground storage tanks, four truck loading/unloading racks (Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, and T-6), three rail car loading/unloading racks (Racks R-1, R-2, and R-3), one barge dock (Barge Dock-C), and a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths (Ship Dock 2/3).  A significant expansion project at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal commenced in 2011.  As a result of this expansion, which is in still in the construction phase, an additional 30 storage tanks as wel

l as additional rail car and truck loading/unloading racks will be operational by the end of 2014.  A biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are also operated on-site to reduce the impact of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal on the environment.



Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Inc. by various modes of transportation cargo containers that can include tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers.  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation modes.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate tank storage.  Similarly, land-based intermodal (IMO) transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control the disposition of the various bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.



The following chemicals presently handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. have been identified by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:



Regulated Toxic Substances in Storage:



Toluene Diisocyanate, Mixed Isomers (CAS Number 26471-62-5)

Vinyl Acetate Monomer (CAS Number 108-05-4)



Regulated Flammable Substances Handled via Intermodal Transfers:



Normal Pentane (CAS Number 109-66-0)

Isopentane (CAS Number 78-78-4)

Normal Pentane (> 45%) / Isopentane (< 55%) Blends



TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulate

d substances at Stolthaven Houston Inc. that are present on-site above their corresponding threshold quantities at all times.  Pentane, Isopentane, and Mixed Pentane Blends are periodically transloaded directly between land-based transportation containers with no intermediate storage in our tanks.  As a result, the above-referenced Pentanes are not always present on-site at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  



Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment through the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated chemicals.



TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS



Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently stores Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) in one 30,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tank (Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-30-10) and in one 15,000-barrel  nominal capacity above-ground storage tank (Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-22).  Tank D-30-10 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 10,600,000-pounds (1,042,000-gallons).  Tank D-15-22 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,131,000-pounds (504,500-gallons).  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston Inc. with no intermediate product storage.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently has over 18-years of experience in the storage and handling of TDI.  



Stolthaven Houston Inc. proposes to commence the storage of TDI in a third above-ground storage tank at the facility:  Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-19.  Storage Tank D-15-19 is an existing low-pressure tank that will have a fill-restricted maximum TDI working capacity of approximately 5,122,000-pounds (503,600-gallons).  TDI storage is currently projected to commence in Tank D-15-19 during the early second quarter

of 2014.  



As part of the changes associated with additional TDI storage, significant modifications will be performed such that TDI can be safely and efficiently handled in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-19 at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  These changes to specific to TDI in Tank D-15-19 include:



- Installing a liner on the storage tank's floor and shell



- Installing a new line constructed of 316L stainless steel from the storage tank to the existing marine dock line in D-Manifold that is used exclusively for TDI marine-based transfers



- Replacing all existing gate valves on the Tank D-15-19 system with new ball valves for ease of operation



- Installing a new stainless steel pump for TDI at Storage Tank D-15-19



- Installing new hot water external heating panels, a water tank, and associated heating panel supply/return lines for Storage Tank D-15-19 while in TDI service



- Insulating Tank D-15-19



- Installing internal eductors at the tank's recirculation line to improve product mixing



- Installing electric tracing and insulation on the tank's lateral line to D-Manifold



- Installing a dehydrator on the tank's vacuum breaker to help prevent moisture from entering the vapor space should there be a loss of plant nitrogen



- Installing a carbon adsorption canister on the Storage Tank D-15-19 vapor line prior to the TDI vapors entering the terminal's common Tank Farm Vent Flare vapor header.  



ISO & NORMAL PENTANE INTERMODAL TRANSFERS



Isopentane, n-Pentane, and Iso/Normal Pentane blends are periodically transloaded directly between land-based transportation containers (i.e. tank trucks, ISO tank containers, and rail tank cars) at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's Rail Rack R-2 and Truck Rack T-6  with no intermediate tank product storage.  Vapors generated during these intermittent transfer operations are directed to the terminal's Tank Farm Vent Flare for pollution control.  



VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS



Stora

ge Tank P-50-5 is an existing internal floating roof (IFR) tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of approximately 50,142-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16,400,000-pounds.  Tank P-50-5, which represents the facility's worst-case VAM release scenario, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and then shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges to rail tank cars with no intermediate product storage, and VAM slops can also be received from marine vessels berthed at Stolthaven Houston.  



As a result of the 2010 VAM storage project for Tank P-50-5, piping modifications were completed in various facility manifolds and at Tank P-50-5 to eliminate the use of hoses in VAM service to the greatest extent possible within the terminal.  A VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to the storage tank.  Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P-50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water as-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.



Employee training related to the specifics of VAM storage and transfer at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal was first conducted in December of 2008 and then again in April of 2009 in preparation of receiving this RMP regulated substance into the facility's A-Tank Farm in 2009.  Although current facility employees have been trained and are experienced in the procedures necessary to safely hand

le VAM, additional safety training related specifically to VAM storage in P-Tank Farm was conducted in December of 2009.  Specific topics covered during this employee review of safe VAM handling procedures included, but were not limited to, the following information:  product transfer modes and affected facility equipment, VAM technical and physical properties, inhibitor specifications and periodic verification, nitrogen blanketing to maintain low oxygen levels, special product hazards and warnings, required personal protective equipment (PPE), and environmental/regulatory considerations.  VAM has been successfully handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. since April of 2009 without significant incident.  



   

? 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:



- Process Safety Information (PSI)



- Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



- ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS)



- Employee Training / Local Training Manual (LTM)



- Mechanical Integrity Program



- Spill Containment



- Management of Change (MOC)



- Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)



- Vapor Control Systems



- Compliance Audits



- Formal Incident Investigation



- Employee Participation Program



- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits



- Departmental / Safety Meetings



- Emergency Response Team (ERT)



- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors



The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.





? 68.155(d):  F

IVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the preceding five years there has been one accidental release from a RMP covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal which resulted in significant property damage on-site.  On the evening of August 23, 2013 nitrogen pressure was being used to unload a rail car containing TDI into one of Stolthaven Houston's on-site TDI storage tanks.  As the rail car was being unloaded, the rail switching crew on-duty coupled the terminal's locomotive to a string of rail cars, including the working TDI rail car, and began to pull the cars away from the rail rack.  As the rail car being emptied of TDI was moved, the TDI cargo hose released from the car, and the car's 1-inch valve connected to the plant nitrogen hose was sheared off.  Residual nitrogen pressure in the rail car caused approximately 4,500-gallons of TDI to be released from the sheared 1-inch valve opening on the rail car into the Rail Rack R-2 concrete containment area, with a small amount of TDI released onto an in-plant concrete road adjacent to the rack in the center of the facility.  There was no off-site release of TDI liquid.  A Stolthaven Houston operator on duty at Rail Rack R-2 immediately closed the rail rack TDI product line valve leading to the storage tank, and the TDI liquid release from the rail car stopped once the residual nitrogen pressure in the car reached atmospheric pressure.  A third party environmental response contractor was contacted within an hour of this release to assist with the necessary clean up efforts, which were completed on the late afternoon of August 27, 2013.



As a result of this incident, the following corrective actions were implemented by Stolthaven Houston Inc. after review by the terminal's Management Steering Committee:  (1) the TDI incident was discussed in detail at a mandatory meeting conducted at Rail Rack R-2 for all facility Operations, Waste Water, and Maintenance Department personnel, (2) Standard Operating Procedures rela

ted to rail car switching were formally updated on September 20, 2013, and (3) operator training related to the revised rail car switching and blue flag procedures was conducted during Operations Departmental meetings held according to shift in September of 2013.  



Note that this incident did not result in any on-site deaths or injuries.  Similarly, there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered processes in the past five years which resulted in known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



All incidents at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO Quality Management System (QMS) to identify and correct the root cause(s) of the events, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.





? 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Stolthaven Houston Inc. is also an active member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).



An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personal injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  





? 68.155(f):  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The following is a list of current initiatives at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to assist in preventing and/or responding to accidental chemical releases, and to

help effectively manage the hazards present at the facility:



- In 2013 Stolthaven Houston hired a third-party consulting firm to perform the three-year RMP compliance audit required pursuant to 40 CFR 68, Sections ?? 68.58 and 68.79.  As a result of this third-party audit, a RMP/PSM Team was formed to address the audit findings.  This team is currently performing a comprehensive review and revision of Stolthaven Houston's RMP/PSM program to better align the program with our current work practices.  As part of this comprehensive internal review, individuals at the facility have been assigned to each of the specific RMP/PSM program elements to promote responsibility and ownership.



- Stolthaven Houston has also contracted with a safety consulting firm to facilitate the five-year Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  We expect to conduct this PHA revalidation for the facility during the first half of 2014.  



- As they become available, toxic and/or flammable product storage tanks at the facility are being equipped with ball valves to replace existing gate valves as part of an ongoing safety enhancement and automation project. 



- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS)



- Employee Suggestion / Experienced Feedback Program



- Regular safety meetings with Stolthaven Houston Operations Department employees and contract 

personnel working in the Stolthaven Houston Terminal



Additional capital budget projects recently implemented or planned for 2014 to improve safety and emergency response at Stolthaven Houston Inc. include the purchase of 1,000-gallons of fire fighting foam, replacing certain fire water delivery lines in A and B-Tank Farms, adding new fire water connections on the east side of D-Tank Farm and in P-Tank Farm, replacing the terminal's spill response boat, purchasing additional fire-fighting equipment and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE

) for the company's emergency response team personnel, additional surveillance cameras to be installed around the terminal's east expansion property, and placing sodium bentonite in A and B-Tank Farms to improve surface working conditions.
